lesson_objectives:
• Time to start a new track! For this track we'll use a lot of static .html and .css files when learning CSS Fundamentals.
  • We need a way to turn in these static files, so we'll make an AppEngine project to serve the static files (and we'll make it have links to all your work in this class)
  • Here is the link to the instructions doc and here is the link to the Github repo.

• HTML elements are primarily described by their tag, which tells the browser what to do with the element.
  • Example tags include: h1, div, span, a, form, img, table, video, ul, etc
  • In addition to the tag for an element there can also be attributes on the tag that can modify the behavior.
  • Example attributes include: id, class, style, src, width, height, alt, etc
  • Note, that in this unit we won't be adding any CSS. We're focusing on only tags and attributes.
  • After this video you should start the Lab for this unit. HTML Basics - Tag Practice Exercises

• The Document Object Model (DOM) for an .html file is a tree like representation of the HTML elements and text on a page.
  • The DOM is not a hard concept, but it's important to understand parent and child relationships when traversing a page.
  • Watch the video then get out a sheet of paper to draw the DOM tree for this code: (put a T for text, don't write it all out)

• There are three ways to add CSS to a web page:
  • Inline CSS - Add CSS to the style attribute on the element directly
  • Embedded CSS - Add CSS within a style element at the top of the .html file. We'll use this approach in our exercises.
  • External CSS - Separating out your CSS into a separate file. This is the recommended approach for real projects.
  • There is a really good site that you should read (now or later) about CSS terminology. Here is that page: http://www.impressivewebs.com/css-terms-definitions/

• The Primary CSS Selectors include by tag, by class, and by id. (name of tag, .className, and #idName)
  • You can use the DOM tree and Combinators to look for elements relative to other elements
  • Here are the ways we'll combine selectors:
  • Descendant Combinator - Space
  • Child Combinator - The > character
  • Same Element - Smashing two selectors together with no space
  • Shortcut delimiter for multiple selectors that share CSS rules - Comma
  • Sibling Combinators - The + symbol and ~ symbol

• Here is the link to the Primary CSS Selectors Lab
  • Download the started code from Github, add it to the /static folder of your Web Links (Static file server) app, then add two lines of code to your main.py file to create the necessary links.
  • Then complete the three exercises (try not to look at the Solutions until AFTER you work the problem)
  • Finally you'll need to deploy your app, visit the deployed version, and submit the URL to your exercise0.html file (assuming you are taking this class for a grade)

• Just wanted to review some details you might have observed when you did the Primary CSS Selectors exercises. Specifically:
  • Comments in CSS, which can only be via /* */
  • Inherited Properties, which properties DO inherit to DOM tree children and which don't.
  • Additionally I wanted to again encourage you to go read this info about CSS terminology, http://www.impressivewebs.com/css-terms-definitions/ (if you didn't read it earlier)

• How do you know who wins in a CSS fight?
  • When there are two conflicting values for the same CSS property, only 1 can win. How does that work?
  • Let's piece it together using some examples.

First we'd like to quickly cover 3 advanced selectors:
  • Attribute selectors - [attribute] or [attribute=someValue] etc (link to more info)
  • Pseudo classes - :hover :nth-child :active :first-child etc (link to more info)
  • Pseudo elements - ::first-letter ::before ::after etc (link to more info)
After the video go work the Advanced CSS Selector Exercises (remember to submit the URL once complete, if taking this class for a grade)

• @media queries give you information about the device a user is viewing the page with and this let's you change the CSS rules specific for their device (width, height, portrait vs landscape orientation, aspect ratio, resolution, etc)
  • We will only teach you about the width media query for a screen, but there are many more @media queries (more info)
  • Here is the link used to see the Responsive UI demo you should check it out.

• In this lessone we'll talk about CSS properties for font, background, and border
  • We'll also make sure you are comfortable with the different ways to set color values
  • Color values can be given by name, hex, rgb, rgba, hsl, and hsla
  • The way I select color is via Chrome Dev Tools. Chrome Dev Tools are awesome in so many ways (love it!)
  • You'll need to download the CSS Property Basics code to follow along.

You can learn more about the font property from w3school font. Details:
  • There are a LOT of CSS properties (list). Trying to learn all the CSS properties would be boring, but I wanted to discuss a few to see things like shorthand tricks.
  • font is a property most websites need in some way so it seemed like an easy one to use for discussion.
  • You'll learn more from the Font Exercises than from me talking. :)

• Visit http://www.google.com/fonts to play with importing a custom font.
  • There are MANY other sites and other ways to import custom fonts. I just like Google and it's easy to demo.
  • In addition to custom fonts we'll show you the text-shadow property
  • Mid video (and after the video) you'll need to work on (then finish) the Font Exercises.

• Let's chat about the background and border properties. Both are easy useful properties that will give you a bit more practice.
  • You can learn more about the background property from w3school background. Details:
  • You'll learn more from the Background and Border Exercises than from me talking. :)

• We'll be discussing the traditional CSS layout properties: display, position, and float
  • With the addition of flex to CSS3 it seemed like these traditional methods would stop being used, but that does not seem to be the case
  • To get you thinking about CSS Layout we'll do a demo, so you need to download the CSS Layout Basics code.
  • Setup the folder in your WebDev links project and open /google_walkthrough/css-walkthrough.html
  • If you would like (completely optional), you can work that walkthrough while watching this video

• The Box Model is simple, but it's important so we'll cover that first.
  • Every box that Chrome draws consist of Content, Padding, Border, and Margin
  • Content, Padding, and Border make up the visual box while Margin is more like a force field keep out zone.

• We will learn about Display, Position, and Float in this unit. This lesson is about Display.
  • The display property can be set to:
  • block - Get your own line (the div default)
  • inline - Ignore width and height settings, snap to the content box and share the line (default for span)
  • inline-block - Respect the width and height settings, but share the line (added more recently to CSS)
  • None - Visually it's like the element never existed

• We will learn about Display, Position, and Float in this unit. This lesson is about Position.
  • The position property can be set to:
  • static - The element takes up space and it is in that space (the default) ignores left, right, top, bottom
  • relative - The element takes up space but it can move relative to the location via left, right, top, bottom.
  • absolute - The element is Out of the Flow, takes up no space and can be a positioned via left, right, top, bottom relative to its nearest positioned ancestor.
  • fixed - The element is Out of the Flow, takes up no space and can be a positioned via left, right, top, bottom relative to the window. Does NOT scroll with page.

• We'll look at the interactions between the display and position properties.
  • There are four options for each so that's 16 possible combinations.
  • We can simplify that some to this 3 by 3 experiment. Let's record what is ignored in each combo.

• Time for your first lab on the CSS Track
  • Here are the instructions for the lab

• We will learn about Display, Position, and Float in this unit. This lesson is about Float.
  • The float property can be set to:
  • none - Don't use float (the default) this is what we've been doing all along
  • left - Slams the element to the left side of the page. Still respects size and position properties.
  • right - Slams the element to the right side of the page. Still respects size and position properties.
  • Float is a very old property and it has a lot of little 'issues'. We'll talk very briefly this time about ways to fix float issues, namely the clear property and setting overflow: hidden; on the parent.
  • There are MANY ways to make what is called a 'clearfix' solution, and we'll talk about it more in a later video.

lesson_title: Interactions between Display, Position, and Float
lesson_objectives:
• Here is the summary of the major rules we'll learn in this lesson:
  • display: none; Like the element was never there (ignore float and position properties).
  • position: absolute; OR position: fixed; Out of the Flow, like an overlying image that takes up no space (ignore display and float properties).
  • float: left; OR float: right; Slam element to the far left or right (ignore display property, respect position if set)
  • Happy combination Respect all properties for static/relative and block/inline/inline-block
  • We'll demo this with a few experiments, but I wanted to tell you conclusion now. :)

• We've seen in the prior lesson and exercises where floats can extend beyond their parent.
  • We fixed that by setting the overflow: hidden; property on the parent.
  • However there are other clearfix issues and various clearfix solutions (good article) that I wanted to warn you about.
  • Next, run through the Google CSS walkthrough again /google_walkthrough/css-walkthrough-round-2.html and see if it makes a lot more sense this pass.
  • If you would like (completely optional), you can work that walkthrough while watching this video
